Sure, here's an example of the anatomy of a perfectly executed self-service translation Hub, using Machine Translation (MT) and Translation Memory (TM) with Post-edit workflow: | Phase | Activities | Tools/Methods | Stakeholders/Actors | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Phase 1: Setup | 1. Determine project scope and goals
2. Choose a TMS with self-service translation features
3. Define user roles and permissions
4. Establish translation memory and machine translation engines
5. Train machine translation engine for domain-specific language
6. Create translation workflow | Translation management system (TMS), Machine Translation engine, Translation Memory tools, post-editing workflow tools | Project manager, translation administrators, MT engineer | | Phase 2: Content Preparation | 1. Upload content to be translated
2. Preprocess the content for translation
3. Analyze content for translation memory matches and machine translation suggestions
4. Assign content to users for translation
5. Train users on self-service translation features and best practices | TMS, Machine Translation engine, Translation Memory tools | Project manager, translation administrators, content owners, end-users | | Phase 3: Translation and Post-Editing | 1. Users translate content using MT and TM suggestions
2. Post-editing is performed according to pre-defined quality criteria and workflow
3. Review and approval of translated content
4. Finalize translations and store in TM for future use | TMS, Machine Translation engine, Translation Memory tools, post-editing workflow tools | Project manager, translation administrators, content owners, end-users | | Phase 4: Integration and Testing | 1. Export and integrate translations into original content
2. Test and validate translations
3. Ensure proper display and functionality of translated content
4. Optimize content for search engines | TMS, UI testing and optimization tools | Project manager, UI developers, TMS administrators | | Phase 5: Post-Launch | 1. Monitor translation performance
2. Collect user feedback
3. Address any issues or bugs
4. Analyze translation metrics and make improvements
5. Continuously update and maintain translations
6. Develop a plan for future updates and enhancements | TMS, Translation analytics and tracking tools | Project manager, translation administrators, content owners, end-users | In this process, the TMS with self-service translation features allows content owners and end-users to easily upload and translate content, with machine translation and translation memory suggestions provided for faster and more accurate translation. Post-editing is performed by either the users or a designated team, with quality criteria and workflow established in advance to ensure consistency and accuracy. The translated content is then integrated into the original content and tested, with optimization for search engines also considered.
